That was IMMENSE!!! That is literally some of the coolest materials science I've seen in YEARS. I wonder how much net strain energy is stored in that bulb, if even the energy of a bullet didn't break the tension/compression coupling in that area ??!! The mechanical wave literally traveled straight to the tail and broke the coupling there! It makes me think of how tempered glass is made! I'm actually really curious now about how light follows the stress variations and separates the wavelengths like a prism, as well as why you can only see it through a polarizing filter, and not in normal light.

It may be the case that the stresses caused by the rapid cooling cause continuously varying, regional strain fields that result in continuous regions of density variation. This would probably mean that along the density fluctuations there is a continuously changing optical index function, the gradient of which could probably be represented by a 3D vector field function, bounded by the Prince Rupert's Drop geometry. Not sure why the strain field can only be seen in polarized light, though.

I was studying your footage. If you were to take two ribbons 1/2"wide of duct tape and run them parallel with the sticky sides facing each other. Put one end on the top of the frame where the string was suspended. Tape the bottom end to a table. Take a single string in between the taped section onto the drop and up to the top of the frame. the tape provides lateral stability while getting ready to shoot and while shooting. The string acts as a back up if the tape gets damaged. I think they are shattering because the rear string  is recoiling and during the shot snapping the drops shattering them. With a more loose way of holding the drop it may change the result.

That quote above the 17th century drawing is worth pondering: "Solus a kingdom One and Strong; but when The top is broken, shivers into Men." Sir Robert Moray's poetic phrase captures the sentiment of English royalists shortly after the Restoration of the English monarchy in 1660. A decade earlier, Parliament tried and executed King Charles I, and (in the estimation of another Royalist, Thomas Hobbes) the death of the king returned the English polity to the condition of nature, "solitary, poor, nasty, brutish and short."

What's interesting here is the timing of the Royal Society's interest in Prince Rupert Drops. According to a 1986 historical study (https://www.jstor.org/stable/531493), King Charles II sent them to the Royal Society in March 1661, just months after he founded that group, and less than a year after his accession to the throne from which his father had been forcibly removed a decade earlier. Whether Charles saw in them a political metaphor or not, his newly appointed scientists weren't slow to use their scientific study of the phenomenon as an opportunity to reinforce Royalist doctrine.

Following +usomat 's idea expressed in his comment on making a perfect spherical Rupert's Drop by fabricating the Rupert's Drop in zero gravity, I would like to propose my own ideas to this topic:

I share the interest of making & seeing a spherical Rupert's Drop without a tail, but I doubt this can be achieved by simply manufacturing it in a "zero gravity" environment. I believe the error lies in the classical method of "dropping" glass into water. Consequently, the hot, fluid glass droplet always has to be somehow seperated from the glass supply, resulting in some tailshape or another. Wether the droplet seperates due to gravity or because it is being manually seperated, it will certainly be impure, meaning it still has a weak spot.

(Maybe a small enough flaw can be overlooked; it depends on the experiment conducted on it, I have no idea of the real scientific value of having a spherical Rupert's Drop, apart from being awesome *)

My thoughts - still disordered from my short brainstorming - include a mixture of acoustic levitation and laserheating. To begin, acoustic levitation (which is a method to make lightweight objects float due to a clever overlapping of soundwaves) gets rid of the need for a "zero gravity" environment. It then is possible to make a small amount of glass - of a diameter of a few millimeters or so - float in mid air. In the next step, I would resort to using some highly powerful lasers to heat this piece of glass to its melting point. The glass will remain in or form a nearly perfect spherical shape in this molten state. Lastly, I would turn off the acoustic levitation device so that the glass can fall into a water tank, solidifying and gaining the well-known strength of a classical Rupert's Drop. We would receive a nearly perfect spherical Rupert's Drop with no tail whatsoever.

What may the benefits of this method be? Well, the most obvious one is a practically flawless Rupert's Drop. Secondly, I estimate the costs and effort of acousticly levitating and laser heating a piece of glass are lower than getting it on the ISS, correct me if I am wrong.

What thoughts on your side did my comment spark? I would welcome you commenting & critisizing on this idea of mine! Maybe there will even be a real discussion :D


PS: Although, why not try earning the attention of NASA or so and attempt creating a Rupert's Drop on the ISS? Hey Destin, as usual your videos are awesome. Its incrdibly fascinating that the drop doesnt shatter even when chips of glass came off of it. If youre willing to continue testing i think the next steps would be to try harder materials. It looks to me like the pure lead of a .22lr is too soft and distributes its force over a large area.

If youre willing to up the caliber to .223rem/5.56NATO or more preferably 308win/7.62NATO we could start testing more complex ammo with stronger material properties. Right off the bat a copper jacketed bullet would do better. Next you could get a monolithic copped bullet (no lead core). Then something like a steel cored penetrator. And finally a tungsten armor piercing.

It would also be cool to see if you could create a prince rupert's drop without a tail. my best guess would be to pour molten glass into a metal container with an open top. Then instantly submerge that into water to get the rapid cooling effect. You could also play around with submersion into liquid nitrogen.

I know these arent chepa experiments, but I can guarentee if you set up a crowd funding site people would happily donate!

this is really cool. an idea for next time might be not tying the tail down so it doesn't snap itself from the impact

I'd say in order for the drop to survive a solid impact, everything needs to move the same way. If there is any variation on the forces applied along the tail, it would open it up kind of like a twig snapping. As soon as there is an opening for the release of the pressure inside, everything starts moving and because of its solidity it can't hold together. I'd also say that the highest chance of the drop surviving a bullet impact would be if it was shot directly in the base of the bulb, and the drop was straight (minimising its ability to have different movements along the tail). Probably the best way to explain the way the tail is broken by the force in the bulb is inertia.

Glass is an amazing material. As part of a project to design a Capillary Electrophoresis (CE) DNA sequencer, I was introduced to fused-silica capillary tubing which is made from the purest form of glass. The capillary tubes we used were 50 microns ID by 360 microns OD, and coated with polyimide polymer for protection from hydrogen embrittlement. A human hair usually could not fit into the inside of this tubing. This tubing could be tied in a simple loop-knot and drawn so tight that the loop diameter could be less than 6mm; if you let go of one end, the knot would quickly untie and recover to a straight shape without any kink or curve! I've never seen any metallic wire or microtube do this. The fused silica seems to be the perfect spring material.
Also interesting is the very high dielectric strength of this fused silica, about 4 kV/mm. Since we used 15 kV for electrophoresis, the tubing could allow a short-circuit through the glass wall when its OD (outside surface) physically contacted a conductive (metallic) electric ground. The short-circuit would punch a nearly perfect, tiny cylindrical hole straight through the tubing wall without breaking the tube! Note that the electrical potential was produced with a charged ion-rich DNA separating aqueous solution that filled the tubing, so the short-circuit was from fluid inside to metal on the outside. Early electrophoretic experiments failed because it was very difficult to find the tiny electrical breaches in the glass wall, some only a few microns in diameter. Only Scanning Electron Microscopic (SEM) images revealed the holes which appeared perfectly round and smooth. Of course, I learned to fully isolate the tubing from conductors, except at the ends. Glass is one of the most exotic materials among many I ever used in engineering.

A tornado warning is something to notify me about; Cloudy with highs in the mid 60s is fine for a forecast that I'll get to in my own time.
